Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black (fired reddish); above, maeander pattern running left in added white above added red band; exterior: on left, part of possible black garment; on right, lower part of female figure in a long chiton (red on left side, black on right side; vertical maeander between parallel lines on the paryphe) to right. Graffito on outside.
Curator's comments: Whilst Lemos does not specifically place this sherd in the Group of Worshippers from the Chalice Style, she does place it within the Chalice Style and the decorative style is similar to others included in this group (British Museum 1924,1201.196; 1924,1201.202). The leading vase from this group is the St Petersburg chalice from Berezan (Lemos no. 964) which bears the degenerate conical chalice form typical of the Chalice Style. The figural decoration on the vase is rendered primarily and carelessly in outline. The handle zone and rim pattern decoration are consistent with other chalices of the same style. Most of the vases in this Chalice Style group display a mixture of techniques consisting of portraying female figures in outline and dancing komasts in black figure. However, none of these features are visible on British Museum 1924,1201.410. Whilst all that is visible of the female figure is her chiton, it is not depicted in outline. Furthermore, the decorative scheme is also very similar to other sherds from Naukratis that are categorised as being in the Grand Style (British School at Athens sherd 13). This sherd would be more appropriately classified in the Grand Style. It is perhaps a late example. The number 813 is written and crossed out in pencil on the interior surface of the sherd. =A1704 is also written in pencil on the interior surface. For parallels regarding the exterior decoration, see UCL 174.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 286, no. 834)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0735) (phase 2)
